title: Publish Multi-Arch Images with Native Platform Builds
teaser: Eliminate emulation bottlenecks by splitting platform builds onto native runners and merging manifests by digest.
useWhen: A single multi-platform build is slow because one or more architectures are built under emulation instead of native runners.
expectedImpact: Lower publish wall-clock time through parallel native platform builds, reduced cache export overhead, and preserved attestations.

prompt.role: You are a CI/CD and container release engineer optimizing Docker Buildx publish workflows for native multi-arch performance and supply-chain metadata correctness.
prompt.objective: Refactor a Docker publish workflow from one emulated multi-platform job into parallel per-platform jobs with native runner routing plus a digest-based manifest merge.
requiredInputs: Current GitHub Actions publish workflow YAML and any caller workflow(s)
Target platform list (for example linux/amd64, linux/arm64, linux/arm/v7, linux/ppc64le, linux/s390x)
Available runner types per platform (GitHub-hosted, self-hosted labels, and any constraints)
Target image names and registries (for example Docker Hub and/or GHCR)
Current tag/version strategy and required workflow outputs
Current cache settings, baseline timings, and any security/scout requirements
tasks: Document the current bottleneck and identify where emulated platforms dominate build time
Design a DAG with a build-test gate, a matrix of per-platform build jobs, and a merge-and-publish job
Implement a platform matrix with an explicit platform-to-runner mapping so each target platform routes to a native runner when available
Use push-by-digest in each platform job, upload digests as artifacts, and merge all digests into final multi-arch manifests per registry
Split cache scopes per platform for registry and GHA caches, and tune cache export mode (for example mode=min) to remove avoidable export overhead
Preserve SBOM/provenance generation on each platform build and include verification steps for manifests, attestations, scout, and overall wall-clock improvement
Define fallback behavior for platforms without native runners (for example keep emulation for only those platforms and document the expected tradeoff)
constraints: Do not use emulation for platforms that have native runner capacity available
Keep the build-test gate as a prerequisite for publish jobs
Preserve existing release tags and required workflow-call outputs unless explicitly instructed otherwise
Keep security/scout checks non-blocking or blocking exactly as defined by current policy and call out any behavior changes
Call out platform-specific limitations (runner availability, unsupported tooling, or architecture-specific build caveats)
outputFormat: Section: Platform-to-runner mapping and proposed job graph
Section: Workflow YAML patch (platform jobs, cache settings, digest artifacts, merge job)
Section: Verification checklist and expected timing deltas
